author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Lakers Are Elite Again, and Ready to ‘Turn Up’
description: The championship mind-set of LeBron James has permeated the team, which is already eyeing the playoffs.
content: Lakers Coach Frank Vogel could have been concerned. The N.B.A. All-Star break was looming and his team still had one more game to go. But Vogel said he could sense from his players, and from LeBron James in particular, that they were focused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: ‘Most Visible Jews’ Fear Being Targets as Anti-Semitism Rises
description: More than half of the hate crimes in New York City last year were attacks on Jewish people. Orthodox Jews are particularly at risk.
content: A rabbinical student was walking down a quiet street in Brooklyn last winter, chatting on the phone with his father when three men jumped him from behind. They punched his head, knocking him to the ground before fleeing down the block.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The Outrageous Costs of Over-Scheduling Your Child
description: Math classes, riding lessons and cleats add up.
content: This piece is part of “The Price of Modern Parenting.” Read about the sandwich generation, caring for aging relatives and the costs of adoption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Eimi Yamamitsu
title: Japan’s Economy Shrank Sharply. Now Comes the Coronavirus.
description: After hits from storms and a tax increase, the world’s No. 3 economy could face recession as the outbreak takes a toll on tourism.
content: TOKYO — Japan’s economy has already been staggered by a devastating typhoon and a wallet-shutting tax increase. Now, the coronavirus that has brought business in neighboring China to a virtual standstill threatens to knock Japan into a full-blown recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Manfred Says Astros’ Shame Is Penalty Enough. Opponents Might Disagree.
description: Commissioner Rob Manfred defended M.L.B.’s handling of the Astros’ cheating scandal. But many fans and players don’t think it went far enough, leaving the door open for more ugliness.
content: NORTH PORT, Fla. — Late Sunday afternoon, just as M.L.B. Commissioner Rob Manfred began his annual spring training news conference in Florida, the Chicago Cubs’ Yu Darvish sent a tweet from Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Nikita Pearl Waligwa, Star of ‘Queen of Katwe,’ Dies at 15
description: The Ugandan teenager, who debuted in the 2016 Disney film about a chess whiz, died of brain cancer, her school said.
content: Nikita Pearl Waligwa, the young Ugandan newcomer who starred in “Queen of Katwe,” the 2016 Disney film about a chess champion’s coming of age, has died of a brain tumor. She was 15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Herrera
title: What to Do With a Day off
description: Step 1: Actually take the day off.
content: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Every Monday, S.L. editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Frakt
title: The Health System We’d Have if Economists Ran Things
description: A survey of nearly 200 Ph.D. health economists finds them taking a few politically unpopular positions.
content: Imagine if American health policy were established by the consensus of health economists. What would the system look like? A survey of nearly 200 Ph.D. health economists working in the United States provides some clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: The Student Loan Appeal Process the Government Doesn’t Tell You About
description: The Education Department has a powerful complaint resolution path that is kept largely out of sight.
content: In the deluge of complaints about a troubled program that pays off student loans for people who work in public service, one stands out for its frequency: Thousands of people say they were misled by loan servicers working on the U.S. government’s behalf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Did Biden Scare Off Our Next President?
description: Imagine the race if other Democrats had not overreacted.
content: More than four years ago, in the run-up to the 2016 presidential campaign, many progressives were hoping Elizabeth Warren would run. Only after she passed on the race — evidently deciding that Hillary Clinton was too strong to be beaten — did a less prominent progressive enter: Bernie Sanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Democrats, Don’t Wish for Your Own Rogue
description: Bloomberg’s record and misleading statements make him a dangerous choice.
content: It is truly a devastating sight to watch liberals who have winced for years at Donald Trump’s issues on wealth, race and women allow fear, propaganda and influence mercenaries to push them into supporting a man who has his own issues concerning wealth, women and race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: The Healthy-Habits Challenge
description: A 28-day plan to nourish your body, mind and spirit, one daily challenge at a time.
content: A 28-day plan to nourish your body, mind and spirit, one daily challenge at a time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Past Remarks Are Challenging for Bloomberg, and Fair Game for Rivals
description: For two months, Michael Bloomberg’s campaign has been preparing for a moment it knew would come: when decades of impolitic and insensitive remarks would face renewed scrutiny.
content: HOUSTON — It hadn’t even been a full day since a 12-year-old video surfaced of Michael R. Bloomberg showing him linking the 2008 financial crisis to the end of redlining, a practice that allowed banks to declare low-income, mostly minority neighborhoods off-limits for loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: ‘Now We Are Refugees’: A Family in Limbo Amid the Coronavirus Outbreak
description: The family of Chloe Chang, a Taiwanese woman, is effectively trapped in Hubei Province, and in the middle of a spat between China and Taiwan.
content: These days, Chloe Chang, a Taiwanese woman stranded at the center of China’s coronavirus outbreak, says she wakes up every half-hour during the night. Sometimes she breaks down in tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sylvie Kauffmann
title: France’s Challenge in Africa
description: The Libyan revolution of 2011 brought lasting terrorist mayhem across a broad reach of Africa’s former French colonies. Now France needs its allies to help pacify the region — if that can be done.
content: PARIS — This is a war that escapes most radar screens. The French, whose troops have been fighting in the Sahel for seven years, ask few questions about their involvement. They should. In this crucible where Islamist insurgency, ancient local conflicts, fragile states, European hesitations and a shifting American strategy make an explosive mix, it is a war they may well be losing — or, in the best case, a war they may never win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: How Millennials Could Make the Fed’s Job Harder
description: They love the idea of retiring early. That could diminish Federal Reserve’s firepower.
content: WASHINGTON — “They say millennials are lazy,” billboards plastered across 15 major cities declared last summer. “Retire early and prove them right.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Salcedo and Derek M. Norman
title: A Latino Worker, a Risky Construction Site and a Family in Mourning
description: Construction workers, many of them undocumented, continue to die on the job in New York City, despite safety regulations.
content: A week before the accident, Segundo Huerta’s wife said, her husband had complained to her that the boss at the Bronx construction site where he was working was pressuring his laborers, berating them for working too slowly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Life of a C.I.A. Coder: Nerf Guns, Pranks and Fat Jokes
description: Trial witnesses describe a raucous workplace culture among officers at the intelligence agency.
content: Inside a secret government building west of Washington, D.C. — past the armed guards, through the turnstiles and coded locks, into a vaulted office with the highest security clearance — sat the Central Intelligence Agency’s team of elite programmers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Hutchinson
title: Pongo Turns Her Struggles Into Pop
description: The Angolan-Portuguese star is winning fans by putting a global spin on African music.
content: LISBON — At an intimate recent gig to celebrate the release of a new EP, the Angolan-Portuguese pop star Pongo’s karate-style kicks punctured the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: She Didn’t Want a Pelvic Exam. She Received One Anyway.
description: Medical schools and students are grappling with an unsettling practice: Performing pelvic exams on unconscious, non-consenting patients.
content: Janine, a nurse in Arizona, checked into the hospital for stomach surgery in 2017. Before the procedure, she told her physician that she did not want medical students to be directly involved. But after the operation, Janine said, as the anesthesia wore off, a resident came by to inform her that she had gotten her period; the resident had noticed while conducting a pelvic exam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Minor Feelings’ Rescues Personal Experience From the Expectations of Others
description: In this collection of essays, Cathy Park Hong writes in ways both polemical and lyrical about her identity as an Asian-American woman.
content: The poet Cathy Park Hong begins her new book of essays with a bang that’s disguised as a tic. In “Minor Feelings,” she recalls an imaginary spasm in her face that marked the beginning of a yearlong depression. Hong, the American-born daughter of Korean immigrants, made an appointment with the only Korean-American therapist she could find who took her insurance, figuring their shared background would give her a reprieve from having to explain herself too much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall Munroe
title: What’s the World’s Worst Smell?
description: Some odors are more heinous than others. Then there’s Stench Soup.
content: What is the most universally disgusting smell to humans?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Benefits of Intermittent Fasting
description: I was skeptical, but it turns out there is something to be said for a daily fast, preferably one lasting at least 16 hours.
content: I’ve long thought the human body was not meant to run on empty, that fasting was done primarily for religious reasons or political protest. Otherwise we needed a reliably renewed source of fuel to function optimally, mentally and emotionally as well as physically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Katie Rogers, Zabihullah Ghazi and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: As Afghan Soldier Kills 2 Americans, Peace Talks Forge Ahead
description: This time when U.S. soldiers are killed by an Afghan, Trump does not call off talks with the Taliban. Is ending the war the only way to end these killings?
content: NANGARHAR, Afghanistan — President Trump stood in a misty drizzle at Dover Air Force Base as the remains of America’s latest two casualties in the long war in Afghanistan arrived home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Dragons, Apes, Mantas and Birds
description: One way to check in on the state of the natural world? Disappear — with your family — in Indonesia’s jungles for two weeks.
content: “Gentlemen,” I said to our boys the night before we left for Indonesia, “are you sure you’re ready to see real dragons?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maxim Trudolyubov
title: Drop the Corruption, Keep the Authoritarianism
description: What is the ultimate goal of Vladimir Putin’s announced plans to shake up the organization of Russia’s governance? Here’s one theory.
content: In Russia, informal hierarchies tend to prevail over formal rules and procedures, or so we have long thought. Long-established democracies are different: They have traditions and regulations in place that set clear limits on nepotism and clan-based politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Coe
title: What We Still Don’t Get About George Washington
description: There continue to be ways to look with fresh eyes at our founding-est founding father.
content: Years into writing a book on George Washington, I noticed something curious about my collection of the popular biographies already written about our first president: All of them were written by white men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aili McConnon
title: Video Game Makers Want to Get Players Off the Couch
description: Developers are offering a physical twist to keep traditional fans interested and draw new ones who are bored with their workouts.
content: Tiffany Ruiz had tried various gyms, apps, workout routines and diets, all in an effort to get fit and lose some weight. “None of them worked because none of them kept my interest,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: A Legal Lion Lays Down His Gavel With a Ruling of ‘Love, Not Hate’
description: After 53 years as a federal judge in Brooklyn, Jack B. Weinstein is retiring. He still has a stubborn belief in the American future.
content: For more than half a century, Judge Jack B. Weinstein was the quintessential activist jurist, using his longtime perch on the federal bench in Brooklyn to champion causes like gun control and school desegregation. In his career — one of the longest in American legal history — he carved out a niche as both a liberal hero and, not surprisingly, a bane for conservatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Van Biema
title: The Bees and Other Creatures of My Childhood Are Disappearing
description: So are my memories of them.
content: I read the other day that bumblebees are in sharp decline, victims of warming temperatures that raise their risk of extinction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Burberry: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Burberry: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Burberry: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: The Place Was Decrepit, but the Price Was Right
description: They didn’t mind renting a fixer-upper, but three years later they’re still working on it.
content: After three years of living in a $1,050-a-month one-bedroom with a shared kitchen in Ridgewood, Queens, Luiza and Ken Li were ready for an upgrade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: JW Anderson: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the JW Anderson: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the JW Anderson: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maxim Trudolyubov
title: Drop the Corruption, Keep the Authoritarianism
description: What is the ultimate goal of Vladimir Putin’s announced plans to shake up the organization of Russia’s governance? Here’s one theory.
content: In Russia, informal hierarchies tend to prevail over formal rules and procedures, or so we have long thought. Long-established democracies are different: They have traditions and regulations in place that set clear limits on nepotism and clan-based politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Coe
title: What We Still Don’t Get About George Washington
description: There continue to be ways to look with fresh eyes at our founding-est founding father.
content: Years into writing a book on George Washington, I noticed something curious about my collection of the popular biographies already written about our first president: All of them were written by white men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Payout From a National Opioids Settlement Won’t Be as Big as Hoped
description: Expectations of a whopping payday set off thousands of lawsuits. But lawyers for the suing cities and states now concede that companies will shell out far less.
content: As talks escalate to settle thousands of opioid-related lawsuits nationwide, a harsh reality is emerging: The money the pharmaceutical industry will pay to compensate ravaged communities will likely be far less than once envisioned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Diamond Princess Evacuations, Xinjiang Document, ‘Love Island’: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: El Cholo’s Last Stand
description: Almost a decade ago, Diego Simeone set out to annoy Europe’s elite with Atlético Madrid. But what happens when the underdog joins the aristocrats?
content: MADRID — Diego Simeone loved the way the sunlight hit the stands at the Vicente Calderón. First as an Atlético Madrid player, and then as its manager, he relished home games in the stadium in late afternoon, when he could look up from the field and see the red and white seats glinting in the waning glow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Just a Few Billion Years Left to Go
description: In “Until the End of Time,” the best-selling physicist Brian Greene explains how the universe will dissolve and what it all meant.
content: UNTIL THE END OF TIME Mind, Matter, and Our Search for Meaning in an Evolving UniverseBy Brian Greene
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aili McConnon
title: Video Game Makers Want to Get Players Off the Couch
description: Developers are offering a physical twist to keep traditional fans interested and draw new ones who are bored with their workouts.
content: Tiffany Ruiz had tried various gyms, apps, workout routines and diets, all in an effort to get fit and lose some weight. “None of them worked because none of them kept my interest,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Payout From a National Opioids Settlement Won’t Be as Big as Hoped
description: Expectations of a whopping payday set off thousands of lawsuits. But lawyers for the suing cities and states now concede that companies will shell out far less.
content: As talks escalate to settle thousands of opioid-related lawsuits nationwide, a harsh reality is emerging: The money the pharmaceutical industry will pay to compensate ravaged communities will likely be far less than once envisioned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘America’s Got Talent’ and ‘Ashley Garcia’
description: “The Champions,” a spinoff talent show, finishes its second season by crowning an ultimate champion. And a new teen series debuts on Netflix.
content: AMERICA’S GOT TALENT: THE CHAMPIONS 8 p.m. on NBC. This spinoff of Simon Cowell’s popular talent show closes out its second season with 10 franchise favorites vying for the title “ultimate champion.” The finalists, all acts that did well on previous seasons of “America’s Got Talent” or international versions of the program, include Alexa Lauenburger, whose dog act won the 2017 German competition, and Marcelito Pomoy, the winner from the Philippines in 2011. The dance group V. Unbeatable, a favorite of the judge Howie Mandel, and Sandou Trio Russian Bar, whose acrobatic performance last week was a standout, are also in contention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: The Place Was Decrepit, but the Price Was Right
description: They didn’t mind renting a fixer-upper, but three years later they’re still working on it.
content: After three years of living in a $1,050-a-month one-bedroom with a shared kitchen in Ridgewood, Queens, Luiza and Ken Li were ready for an upgrade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus, Michael Bloomberg, Mississippi Flooding: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here's what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: JW Anderson: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the JW Anderson: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the JW Anderson: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Katie Waldman and Stephen Miller Wed at Trump Hotel
description: Katie Waldman, Vice President Mike Pence’s press secretary, marries Stephen Miller, a senior adviser to President Trump, at the Trump International Hotel in Washington.
content: Katie Rose Waldman and Stephen Miller, who both work in the Trump White House, were married Feb. 16 at Trump International Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Aryeh Lightstone, who is a senior adviser to David Friedman, the United States ambassador to Israel, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Burberry: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Burberry: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Burberry: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: A Rape Suspect Was Released. 3 More Women Were Attacked.
description: A series of mistakes underscored a longstanding problem in the N.Y.P.D.’s Special Victims division.
content: One frigid morning in January 2019, a New York University student woke up in her apartment near the school’s Manhattan campus to find a masked man standing over her in bed. He told her not to scream, she told investigators, and then he held her down and raped her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: This Is the Best Lasagna on the Planet
description: Regina Schrambling’s version, from 2001, has a beauty that’s “more than cheese deep.” Make it soon.
content: Good morning. It’s Presidents’ Day and many of you, I hope, are free of work obligations and looking to cook one of those dishes that only three-day weekends seem to make possible. Like, for instance, Regina Schrambling’s amazing recipe for lasagna (above).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Gunmen Kill at Least 24 at Church in Burkina Faso
description: There was no claim of responsibility for the attack at Sunday Mass, but jihadist groups have been trying to gain control of rural areas.
content: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Gunmen killed at least 24 people, including a pastor, in an attack on a church during Sunday Mass in northwestern Burkina Faso, four security sources said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Adam Scott Emerges From Crowded Field to Win Genesis Open
description: Scott finished at 11-under 273, holding off a tight group of contenders, for his first PGA Tour title since 2016.
content: LOS ANGELES — Adam Scott has another victory at Riviera, and this time it counts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Gunmen Kill at Least 24 at Church in Burkina Faso
description: There was no claim of responsibility for the attack at Sunday Mass, but jihadist groups have been trying to gain control of rural areas.
content: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Gunmen killed at least 24 people, including a pastor, in an attack on a church during Sunday Mass in northwestern Burkina Faso, four security sources said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: When a Picture Is Worth a Thousand Tears
description: Photos of suffering children have the power to soften sentiment toward the “other.” Can that still happen in a polarized age?
content: NASHVILLE — On June 8, 1972, Nick Ut, a Vietnamese photographer working for The Associated Press, shot a now-iconic photo of children fleeing napalm mistakenly dropped on their village by South Vietnamese forces. At the center of the photo is a naked 9-year-old girl named Phan Thi Kim Phuc. She is in agony; her skin appears to be melting. None of the helmeted soldiers in the background are looking at the children. Only the photographer sees her pain.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2 Million in California
description: A Craftsman-style home in Marin County, a 1968 house outside of San Francisco and a Spanish-style retreat in La Jolla.
content: A Craftsman-style home in Marin County, a 1968 house outside of San Francisco and a Spanish-style retreat in La Jolla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Dufort and Jane How
title: Spring’s Riotously Colorful Dresses
description: This season’s most vibrant statement pieces leave room for movement — and don’t skimp on texture or pattern, either.
content: While some designers have lately adopted rigid sculptural silhouettes in their collections, others have taken that same penchant for volume and turned it toward looser, easier pieces. Take, for example, Valentino’s spring 2020 collection, in which a series of crisp white looks with wide skirts and exaggerated puff sleeves gave way to billowy floor-grazing tiered dresses in vibrant fuchsia, orange and chartreuse. Jil Sander’s Luke and Lucie Meier and Dior’s Maria Grazia Chiuri, by contrast, created drama with multidimensional textiles adorned with fringe or straw. To capture these collections, and some of the season’s other most kinetic looks, the photographer Johnny Dufort and stylist Jane How chose fittingly spectacular settings: the fantastical rooms of the Italian art hotel Atelier Sul Mare and Sicily’s northern coast. There, the waves, the flash of the camera and the dresses (as well as a few separates) came together to create images that are constantly in motion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Christopher Kane: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Christopher Kane: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Christopher Kane: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Kamau Brathwaite, Poet Who Celebrated Caribbean Culture, Dies at 89
description: The peoples of the Caribbean needed to rediscover their heritage, he said, adding, “Instead of developing a sense of ourselves, we developed a false sense of Europe.”
content: Kamau Brathwaite, whose lyrical poetry wove together the history and imagery of his native Barbados, the Caribbean and the African diaspora, as well as his personal experiences, died on Feb. 4 at his home in Barbados. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: A Rape Suspect Was Released. 3 More Women Were Attacked.
description: A series of mistakes underscored a longstanding problem in the N.Y.P.D.’s Special Victims division.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: This Is the Best Lasagna on the Planet
description: Regina Schrambling’s version, from 2001, has a beauty that’s “more than cheese deep.” Make it soon.
content: Good morning. It’s Presidents’ Day and many of you, I hope, are free of work obligations and looking to cook one of those dishes that only three-day weekends seem to make possible. Like, for instance, Regina Schrambling’s amazing recipe for lasagna (above).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Johnson Faces Scrutiny for Flooding Response After Storm Dennis
description: The prime minister has no plans to visit areas with heavy flooding, his office said, and he has not called a meeting of the government’s emergencies committee.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s response to a storm that battered the country over the weekend, causing severe flooding in hundreds of towns and villages, prompted a backlash from critics inside and outside his party on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: 6 Cooper Hewitt Trustees Resign After Director’s Removal
description: The board members said they should have been consulted before the Smithsonian asked Caroline Baumann to resign after an investigation.
content: Six trustees, among them the prominent designer David Rockwell, have resigned from the board of the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum to protest the removal of the museum’s director, Caroline Baumann, following an investigation into issues including her 2018 wedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Jeff Bezos Commits $10 Billion to Address Climate Change
description: The world’s richest man unveiled a fund to help climate scientists and activists, an escalation of his philanthropic efforts.
content: SEATTLE — Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive and the world’s richest man, said on Monday that he was committing $10 billion to address the climate crisis in a new initiative he called the Bezos Earth Fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Williams
title: Virginia Legislature Turns Down Ban on Military-Style Weapons
description: A Virginia State Senate committee rejected a proposal to ban assault-style rifles, showing the limits of Democratic efforts to impose restrictive gun-control laws.
content: A bill that would have banned military-style rifles in Virginia was defeated in the State Senate on Monday, a sign of the limited power of the state’s new Democratic majority in enacting the most restrictive elements of its gun-control agenda and a blow to Gov. Ralph Northam’s efforts to restrict gun possession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Feisty All-Star Finish a Fitting Tribute to Bryant
description: Pregame tributes and fourth-quarter fireworks provide a spiritual lift at a revamped N.B.A. All-Star Game.
content: CHICAGO — The N.B.A.’s 69th All-Star Game played out just as it was billed — and it also veered wildly off script to a delicious degree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Dawn Mello, Who Revived Bergdorf Goodman and Gucci, Dies at 88
description: She was one of the first women to rise to leadership in retailing, and her aesthetic helped shift the landscape of American fashion.
content: Donna Karan reminisced recently about a morning in the early 1980s when she saw the first collection she had designed under her own label showcased in the windows of Bergdorf Goodman. She stood outside transfixed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: How China Tracked Detainees and Their Families
description: A leaked government document shows how people were monitored and selected for internment camps in Xinjiang.
content: The last time she heard from her family was over three years ago, before China began rounding up Muslims in the country’s far west. She lived abroad and knew nothing of her family’s fate — until the contents of a leaked government document surfaced, describing their lives in chilling detail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: A TV Star’s Suicide Prompts a Blame Game in Britain
description: Caroline Flack’s death over the weekend is the latest tragedy to highlight Britain’s peculiar tabloid culture.
content: LONDON — On Saturday night, news broke in Britain that Caroline Flack — the former host of “Love Island,” a wildly popular reality TV show — had killed herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Levin
title: No Room Service, but History’s on the Menu
description: An immersive theater project in a dilapidated hotel aims to reanimate a Miami neighborhood’s past. It’s popular, but is it sanitizing gentrification?
content: MIAMI — With its boarded-up facade eerily lit by a round Miami Beach moon, the Ocean Terrace Hotel looks abandoned. But when the blank metal doors swung open on a recent February evening, history suddenly came to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Battling Coronavirus, China Signals Delay of Its Top Party Gathering
description: The likely postponement of the most important spectacle on China’s political calendar reflects the Communist Party’s growing anxiety over the epidemic.
content: China signaled on Monday that it would postpone its most important political spectacle of the year, a sign of deepening anxiety within the ruling Communist Party about the threat posed by the coronavirus epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Aide Quits After Furor Over Racial Comments
description: The resignation came after silence from Downing Street about an adviser who once said blacks have lower IQs than whites.
content: LONDON — The warning signs may have been there last month when Dominic Cummings, the influential and iconoclastic aide to Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, invited “weirdos and misfits” to apply to work at Downing Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Apple Signals Coronavirus’s Threat to Global Businesses
description: Supply is a problem, the company warned, as factories slowly reopen in China, and demand is down, too, with stores there still mostly closed.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple on Monday became one of the first companies to reveal how the coronavirus that has gripped China was affecting its business, saying it was cutting its sales expectations for this quarter, which a month ago it had projected to be robust.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cruise Ship Passengers, Some Infected, Flown Back to U.S.
description: As passengers were evacuated from one ship in Japan, health officials scrambled to test people on another, in Cambodia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Aide Quits After Furor Over Racial Comments
description: The resignation came after silence from Downing Street about an adviser who once said blacks have lower IQs than whites.
content: LONDON — The warning signs may have been there last month when Dominic Cummings, the influential and iconoclastic aide to Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, invited “weirdos and misfits” to apply to work at Downing Street.

author: By Lynn Yaeger
title: The Artists Keeping Up the Tradition of Mask-Making
description: The ancient accessories are being embraced by a new creative generation.
content: THE IMPULSE TO transform one’s visage is an elemental one, practiced by every culture on earth. From the African continent to the Inuit societies of North America to the islands of Oceania, ancient peoples used materials like mud, wood, bone, feathers and metals to craft masks made for everything from conjuring rain to guiding the dead into the spiritual realm. Aside from ceremony, masks have also long had practical implications: Think of the medico della peste, or “plague doctor” mask, with its long, birdlike beak, which was worn in the 17th century by physicians hoping to protect themselves from the Black Plague, and which became one of the enduring visual images from that time, a metaphor for the facelessness of death itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A Craftsman-style home in Marin County, a 1968 house outside of San Francisco and a Spanish-style retreat in La Jolla.
content: The town of Fairfax is in Marin County, which was home to some of the country’s most famous musicians in the 1960s, including Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead. In 2013, the town declared Aug. 7 Jerry Garcia Day to honor the musician, who died in 1995; the declaration was made in Contratti Park, where the Grateful Dead and their friends in Jefferson Airplane played softball in the 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Anthony
title: Ink Rx? Welcome to the World of Paramedical Tattoos
description: Needles and pigments are helping medical patients heal emotionally.
content: HECKER, Ill. — The first fingernail tattoo started off as a joke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: How Colum McCann Shaped Loss Into a Book
description: “Apeirogon,” the latest novel from the National Book Award winner, delves into the Israeli-Palestinian conflict through the eyes of two grieving fathers.
content: “I’m a bit of a magpie,” Colum McCann said, sheepishly gesturing around his office at Hunter College.
source.name: The New York Times

title: These Devices Can Prevent Major Home Damage and Save You Money
description: Smart-home sensors can detect leaks, frozen pipes, and open doors so that small problems don’t turn into big expenses.
content: I don’t like surprises, especially the kind that cost me money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Americans Heading From Cruise Ship to Quarantine
description: More than 300 Americans were evacuated from a contaminated cruise ship in Japan. Fourteen of them tested positive for the coronavirus and will be placed in isolation in the United States.
content: More than 300 Americans were evacuated from a contaminated cruise ship in Japan. Fourteen of them tested positive for the coronavirus and will be placed in isolation in the United States.

author: By Lillian Guerra
title: Fear and Loathing in Havana and Miami
description: Cubans in Florida and on the island are united by a common history. But the past also divides them.
content: MIAMI — As most people who have grown up Cuban in the United States over the last six decades would attest, asking their parents about the Cuban Revolution tends to elicit one of three reactions: silence, suspicion or enthusiastic invocations of gratitude that you are not in Cuba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Edward Wong
title: They Escaped an Infected Ship, but the Flight Home Was No Haven
description: The U.S. had said cruise ship passengers infected with the coronavirus would not be allowed on evacuation flights, but the decision was apparently reversed at the last minute.
content: TOKYO — The ground rules were clear. A day before 328 Americans were to be whisked away from a contaminated cruise ship in Japan, the U.S. Embassy in Tokyo told passengers that no one infected with the coronavirus would be allowed to board charter flights to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Reed
title: Charles Portis, Elusive Author of ‘True Grit,’ Dies at 86
description: The publicity-shy Mr. Portis earned a modest but devoted readership and accolades as America’s “least-known great writer.”
content: Charles Portis, the publicity-shy author of “True Grit” and a short list of other novels that drew a cult following and accolades as the work of possibly the nation’s best unknown writer, died on Monday at a hospice in Little Rock, Ark. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Mickey Wright, One of the Greatest Players in Women’s Golf, Dies at 85
description: She who won 82 L.P.G.A. tournaments, 13 of them majors, dominating the tour in the late 1950s and much of the 1960s.
content: Mickey Wright, who won 82 L.P.G.A. tournaments, 13 of them majors, and was perhaps the finest player in the history of women’s golf, died on Monday in Florida. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: With Libya Still at War, E.U. Agrees to Try Blocking Weapons Flow
description: The European Union decides to mount a naval and air mission to curb weapons to Libya, overcoming objections from populist governments that feared it could result in increased migration to Europe.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union agreed on Monday to launch a new naval and air mission to stop more arms reaching the warring factions in Libya, overcoming initial objections from Austria and Hungary, which feared the ships might attract migrants and enable more of them to reach Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Owen Bieber, Auto Workers’ President During Period of Decline, Dies at 90
description: Faced with automation and competition from foreign car companies, he was forced to make concessions in an effort to preserve jobs.
content: Owen F. Bieber, who as president of the United Auto Workers from 1983 to 1995 steered a proud former flagship of unionism through an era of declining bargaining power, falling membership and contracts limited by harsh economic realities, died on Monday.  He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck
title: Biden, Seeking Revival, Is Counting on at Least Second Place in Nevada
description: Joe Biden’s first two finishes sent his national poll numbers plummeting and put his donors on edge. He wants Nevada to begin his comeback, not accelerate his plunge.
content: LAS VEGAS — On Friday afternoon, Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign manager, Greg Schultz, convened a conference call with supporters to outline a path forward following two bruising losses in Iowa and New Hampshire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Slowed by the Coronavirus, China Inc. Struggles to Reopen
description: Some factories are firing up again, but with many workers quarantined and parts in short supply, production is limited.
content: Airbus is slowly restarting its assembly line in China. General Motors began limited production on Saturday. Toyota followed on Monday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Readers respond to an Op-Ed calling on parents to support healthy cafeteria food instead.

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: China Detains Activist Who Accused Xi of Coronavirus Cover-Up
description: Xu Zhiyong, a prominent Chinese legal activist, went silent over the weekend. His girlfriend, Li Qiaochu, a social activist, has gone missing.
content: He portrayed China’s leader, Xi Jinping, as hungry for power. He accused Mr. Xi of trying to cover up the coronavirus outbreak in central China. In one of his most daring writings, he urged Mr. Xi to resign, saying, “You’re just not smart enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Jentleson
title: Why Don’t We Know Which Democratic Candidate Can Beat Trump?
description: We seem to know less than we did at the beginning of the primary.
content: The Democratic presidential primary is starting to feel less like a political contest and more like an existential experiment. In the era of big data and after a year of micro-analyzing every little twist and turn, we seem to know less than we did at the beginning. In an era when we’re supposed to know everything, we somehow seem to know nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Young, Conservative and Working for Trump? The Dating Pool Is Small
description: Washington’s highly politicized culture can be brutal on dating life. For Trump aides, one solution is to find love with each other.
content: WASHINGTON — Stephen Miller and Katie Waldman, who met while he was developing the administration’s restrictive immigration policies and she was working as a spokeswoman for the Department of Homeland Security, were married at President Trump’s hotel on Sunday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Senator Tom Cotton Repeats Fringe Theory of Coronavirus Origins
description: Scientists have dismissed suggestions that the Chinese government was behind the outbreak, but it’s the kind of tale that gains traction among those who see China as a threat.
content: The rumor appeared shortly after the new coronavirus struck China and spread almost as quickly: that the outbreak now afflicting people around the world had been manufactured by the Chinese government.

title: Watch Mars Disappear Behind the Moon in the Early Morning Sky
description: In what is known as an occultation, Mars will briefly be blocked by the moon on Tuesday morning.
